description: Ina Cramer of Sherrill celebrated her 100th birthday May 21, but she might not have made it if her doctor was right about her chances after a heart attack. Joined by son Mark Cramer and daughter-in-law Carol Cramer, Ina recently shared her stories and the secret of her longevity from her Noyes Manor home. There was even an official proclamation from Sherrill mayor...
text:
Ina Cramer of Sherrill celebrated her 100th birthday May 21, but she might not
have made it if her doctor was right about her chances after a heart attack.
She was given only 10 years to live by her surgeon at the time.

That was nearly 50 years ago.

A more recent visit with a much younger doctor brought amazement as he saw
just how much she had survived in her life. She joked and asked him who was
thumbing their nose now, as three of her former surgeons had predeceased her.
That young doctor told Ina in beating those odds she had taught him not to
assume what he knew from a textbook to be absolute ever again.

Joined by son Mark Cramer and daughter-in-law Carol Cramer, Ina recently
shared her stories and the secret of her longevity from her Noyes Manor home.
Her 100th birthday was celebrated there in style with a gala parade of well-
wishers riding through the parking lot as she sat with friends outside, with
the festively-decorated vehicles of family and friends joined with Sherrill
police cars and firetrucks.

There was even an official proclamation from Sherrill mayor Bill Vineall
designating May 21, 2020 as "Ina Cramer Day" in the Silver City.

Born Ina Blodgett, her birthdays growing up were always a special time,
especially when she lived on Cazenovia Lake during the days of her youth.
Then, she and her sister Roberta celebrated the occasion with an annual swim
across the length of the lake, with one of them in a rowboat and the other
swimming alongside. After the trip they switched positions so the other could
also enjoy a brisk swim.

That ritual happened every year regardless of the weather and some of those
lake outings in mid-May were quite cold, Ina remembered.

Her father worked as a caretaker for the wealthy Fairchild family. Ina and her
own family lived at the Fairchild's big home on the lake, so although Ina
didn't come from a rich family herself she was surrounded by finery. Ina said
she really appreciated all the Fairchilds did for her own family, calling them
"wonderful" people.

Ina recalled the days in her Cazenovia hometown when she could walk to school
or to the dress shop or grocery store right downtown on Albany Street. Now,
much of the shopping is done out of town, she noted.

She married her husband DeForest Cramer in 1942. During World War II, DeForest
joined the service and Ina worked as a civilian on a naval base in Florida.
After the war, the couple lived in Morrisville where Ina worked as the
superintendent's administrative assistant in the Morrisville-Eaton Central
School district.

Ina and DeForest moved to Ransom Avenue in Sherrill in 1993. DeForest passed
away on his 80th birthday in 2002 and she relocated just a few blocks over to
Noyes Manor in 2007.

The couple had two sons and daughters-in-law, Mark and Carol and Jack and his
wife Pat. There are Mark and Carol's kids Andrew and his wife Katie, Audra and
her boyfriend Tom and Caira and her husband Mike; Jack and Pat's kids Amy and
her husband Raj and Meegan and her husband Joe; and great-grandchildren
Cadence, Cruz, Karina, Lance, Lily, Levi, Luke and Ravi.

One of her biggest joys in life has always been visits with her children,
grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

"I've always had family around me," Ina said.

Mark admitted his days as a child himself were sometimes spent hiding from his
mother, although she was simply trying to do what was best for him. He
recalled whenever he got a scrap, Mom was quick to grab her healing  but
stinging  bottle of iodine.

"It got to the point where I would try to hide my injuries to avoid the pain
of the iodine," he remembered.

His parents also used to flood their backyard during the chill of winter to
create an ice skating rink, Mark added.

Ina said one of the technological advances that impressed her the most in her
lifetime was the introduction of color television. She was also quite amazed
only two years ago to watch Audra's college commencement streamed from
Scotland, as she viewed it from Mark and Carol's own Sherrill home.

Mark said Ina was always very disciplined and did whatever her doctor
recommended. She admitted she didn't really feel she had a "secret" to her
longevity  she just always took every day as it came and welcomed each one.

When asked for her advice for the young people of today, Ina encouraged them
all to take everything that comes at them in stride.

"You have to just accept it," she explained. "If you don't accept it you will
be left along the wayside. Nobody ever left me along the wayside."

DeForest worked as a "scout" for antiques dealers and Ina took a liking to the
old-time items as well. Carol said their own home boasts many quality antique
pieces thanks to the expert eye of her in-laws.

Mark joked that her interest in antiquities has taken on an even bigger
importance in his mother's life.

"Now we are telling her that she has become an antique herself," he said.

To see a video from the birthday parade, find the Mid-York Weekly on Facebook.

title: Centenarian advises today's youth to accept life's challenges
html:
Ina Cramer of Sherrill celebrated her 100th birthday May 21, but she might not have made it if her doctor was right about her chances after a heart attack. She was given only 10 years to live by her surgeon at the time.

That was nearly 50 years ago.

A more recent visit with a much younger doctor brought amazement as he saw just how much she had survived in her life. She joked and asked him who was thumbing their nose now, as three of her former surgeons had predeceased her. That young doctor told Ina in beating those odds she had taught him not to assume what he knew from a textbook to be absolute ever again.

Joined by son Mark Cramer and daughter-in-law Carol Cramer, Ina recently shared her stories and the secret of her longevity from her Noyes Manor home. Her 100th birthday was celebrated there in style with a gala parade of well-wishers riding through the parking lot as she sat with friends outside, with the festively-decorated vehicles of family and friends joined with Sherrill police cars and firetrucks.

There was even an official proclamation from Sherrill mayor Bill Vineall designating May 21, 2020 as "Ina Cramer Day" in the Silver City.

Born Ina Blodgett, her birthdays growing up were always a special time, especially when she lived on Cazenovia Lake during the days of her youth. Then, she and her sister Roberta celebrated the occasion with an annual swim across the length of the lake, with one of them in a rowboat and the other swimming alongside. After the trip they switched positions so the other could also enjoy a brisk swim.

That ritual happened every year regardless of the weather and some of those lake outings in mid-May were quite cold, Ina remembered.

Her father worked as a caretaker for the wealthy Fairchild family. Ina and her own family lived at the Fairchild's big home on the lake, so although Ina didn't come from a rich family herself she was surrounded by finery. Ina said she really appreciated all the Fairchilds did for her own family, calling them "wonderful" people.

Ina recalled the days in her Cazenovia hometown when she could walk to school or to the dress shop or grocery store right downtown on Albany Street. Now, much of the shopping is done out of town, she noted.

She married her husband DeForest Cramer in 1942. During World War II, DeForest joined the service and Ina worked as a civilian on a naval base in Florida. After the war, the couple lived in Morrisville where Ina worked as the superintendent's administrative assistant in the Morrisville-Eaton Central School district.

Ina and DeForest moved to Ransom Avenue in Sherrill in 1993. DeForest passed away on his 80th birthday in 2002 and she relocated just a few blocks over to Noyes Manor in 2007.

The couple had two sons and daughters-in-law, Mark and Carol and Jack and his wife Pat. There are Mark and Carol's kids Andrew and his wife Katie, Audra and her boyfriend Tom and Caira and her husband Mike; Jack and Pat's kids Amy and her husband Raj and Meegan and her husband Joe; and great-grandchildren Cadence, Cruz, Karina, Lance, Lily, Levi, Luke and Ravi.

One of her biggest joys in life has always been visits with her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

"I've always had family around me," Ina said.

Mark admitted his days as a child himself were sometimes spent hiding from his mother, although she was simply trying to do what was best for him. He recalled whenever he got a scrap, Mom was quick to grab her healing – but stinging – bottle of iodine.

"It got to the point where I would try to hide my injuries to avoid the pain of the iodine," he remembered.

His parents also used to flood their backyard during the chill of winter to create an ice skating rink, Mark added.

Ina said one of the technological advances that impressed her the most in her lifetime was the introduction of color television. She was also quite amazed only two years ago to watch Audra's college commencement streamed from Scotland, as she viewed it from Mark and Carol's own Sherrill home.

Mark said Ina was always very disciplined and did whatever her doctor recommended. She admitted she didn't really feel she had a "secret" to her longevity – she just always took every day as it came and welcomed each one.

When asked for her advice for the young people of today, Ina encouraged them all to take everything that comes at them in stride.

"You have to just accept it," she explained. "If you don't accept it you will be left along the wayside. Nobody ever left me along the wayside."

DeForest worked as a "scout" for antiques dealers and Ina took a liking to the old-time items as well. Carol said their own home boasts many quality antique pieces thanks to the expert eye of her in-laws.

Mark joked that her interest in antiquities has taken on an even bigger importance in his mother's life.

"Now we are telling her that she has become an antique herself," he said.

To see a video from the birthday parade, find the Mid-York Weekly on Facebook.
